<extra_id_1>1

A computer virus is a type of malicious software designed to spread itself across computers without user consent. It can replicate by inserting copies of its code into other executable files or documents, which then spreads when those files are shared.

Malware, on the other hand, refers to any form of malicious software, including viruses, worms, trojans, ransomware, spyware, adware, and more. While all malware is intended to cause harm, they differ in their methods and objectives. For example, while a worm may spread rapidly through networks like a virus, it does not necessarily need to infect individual programs or files to do so. A trojan horse, meanwhile, tricks users into installing it under false pretenses before causing damage once installed.
